metadata.title: Hierarchical micro-nano structured Ti6Al4V surface topography via two-step etching process for enhanced hydrophilicity and osteoblastic responses

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science and Engineering C
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /msec
Hierarchical micro-nano structured Ti6Al4V surface topography via two-step etching process for enhanced hydrophilicity and osteoblastic responses
Byeong-Seok Moon, Sungwon Kim, Hyoun-Ee Kim, Tae-Sik Jang ⁎ Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul 151-742, Republic of Korea
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: cgamja@snu.ac.kr (T.-S. Jang).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.msec.2016.12.064 0928-4931/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 25 August 2016 Received in revised form 18 November 2016 Accepted 13 December 2016 Available online 18 December 2016
Hierarchical micro-nano (HMN) surface structuring of dental implants is a fascinating strategy for achieving fast and mechanically stable fixation due to the synergetic effect of micro- and nano-scale surface roughness with surrounding tissues. However, the introduction of awell-defined nanostructure on amicrostructure having complex surface geometry is still challenging. As a means of fabricating HMN surface on Ti6Al4V-ELI, target-ion induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) was used onto a sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched substrate. The HMN surface topography was simply controlled by adjusting the tantalum (Ta) target power of the TIPS technique, which is directly related to the Ta ion flux and the surface chemical composition of the substrate. Characterization using scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM), transmission electronmicroscopy (TEM), and laser scanningmicroscopy (LSM) verified that well-defined nano-patterned surface structures with a depth of ~300 to 400 nm and a width of ~60 to 70 nmwere uniformly distributed and followed the complex micron-sized surface geometry. In vitro cellular responses of pre-osteoblast cells (MC3T3-E1)were assessed by attachment and proliferation of cells on flat, nano-roughened, micro-roughened, and an HMN surface structure of Ti6Al4V-ELI. Moreover, an in vivo dogmandible defect model study was used to investigate the biological effect of the HMN surface structure compared with the micro-roughened surface. The results showed that the surface nanostructure significantly increased the cellular activities of flat and micro-roughened Ti, and the bone-to-implant contact area and new bone volume were significantly improved on the HMN surface structured Ti. These results support the idea that an HMN surface structure on Ti6Al4V-ELI alloy has great potential for enhancing the biological performance of dental implants.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Titanium alloys Roughness treatments Surface structure Bone regeneration Dental implant

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Titanium (Ti) and Ti-based alloys have beenwidely used as biomedicalmaterials due to their relatively low specificweight, excellent corrosion resistance, and satisfactory biocompatibility [1–3]. Among them, Ti6Al4V-ELI, which possesses superior mechanical properties, is the most favored Ti-based alloy havingwide applications as an implantmaterial in dentistry [4,5]. However, in clinical situations, the formation of indirect bone contact with intervening fibrous tissue causes many concerns about the practical use of Ti alloys [6–9]. The clinical success of dental implants has been found to be totally determined by the fast and mechanically stable fixation of material; early osseointegration, direct contact between the implant surface and surrounding bone, is generally obtained from surface modifications such as modifying the chemical composition or surface roughness [10–12].
Among the various surface modification techniques, sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched (SLA) is the most successfully commercialized surface treatment for Ti-based dental implants [13,14]. The micron-sized surface structures provide strong mechanical interlocking effect and large bone-to-implant contact area for stable fixation of the implants [12]. However, in the case of Ti-based alloys, inferior osteoblast cell adhesion behavior in the early stage of the implantation of SLAtreated Ti-based alloys still remains as the main problem [13,15].
Recently, nanostructuring on a surfacewithmicron-sized roughness has been proposed to induce fast regeneration of the surrounding tissues by regulating the protein interactions [16] and cellular behavior due to its similar dimensions with the extracellular matrix [17]. Due to these distinguishable advantages of the nanostructure compared with the microstructure [16,18], a hierarchical micro-nano (HMN) structure is very promising as a result of their synergetic effects [19]. In addition, the structural similarity of an HMN structure with natural bone that is hierarchically composed of macro-, micro-, and nano-scale components may provide a more suitable surface environment for the cell functions of bone tissue [20]. The biological advantages of the HMN structures
have been demonstrated by several researchers in in vitro [20–24] and in vivo [19,25] circumstances. However, most HMN structures of Ti are fabricated using ceramic-based surface modification techniques such as anodizing [20] and oxidation [22,23]. Although there has been remarkable improvement, the ceramic layer has always exhibited a latent problem related to delamination or cracking due to its weak interfacial strength and brittleness [26].
Target-ion induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) is a recently developed technique which combines the advantages of conventional ion beam etching and sputtering; conventional ion beam etching can fabricate nano-scale surface structures while maintaining metallic properties [27–29], and sputtering can fabricate such surface structures on a large surface area in mass-production [30,31]. The TIPS technique is basically based on sputtering, but extremely high negative substrate bias induced target-ion induced etching phenomenon on the surface. When tantalum (Ta) was used as a target material, a highly porous titanium surface created with Ta ion incorporation exhibited not only excellent biocompatibility, but also enhanced osteoblast responses in in vitro situations [26,32].
Here, it is reported that a facile fabrication method for producing an HMN structure using TIPS on an SLA-treated Ti6Al4V-ELI substrate that produces a well-defined nanostructure on the minimally reduced microstructure of the SLA-treated substrate. The optimal conditions of TIPS were investigated in terms of the target ion flux under a high negative bias substrate voltage. To evaluate the biological effects of the HMN structure, the attachment and proliferation of pre-osteoblast cells (MC3T3-E1) were tested in vitro. Furthermore, a bone regeneration experimentwas assessed using in vivo pilot studywith dogmandible defect model for the practical use of this method.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
2.1. Surface modification via TIPS
Nanostructured surfaces were fabricated using the TIPS method with a DCmagnetron sputter (Ultech) and a Ta target (75⌀ ×5mm, purity 99.99%, Kojundo) [26,32]. Prior to processing, Ti6Al4V-ELI (Carpenter) disks (n = 40) with dimensions of 10⌀ ×5 mm were polished using 2000 grit sandpaper, followed by ultrasonic cleaning. A polished sample was loaded in front of the target at a distance of 6.5 cm and the deposition chamberwas thenpumped to 3.8×10−3mTorr using rotary and diffusion pumps. TIPS was conducted in a high-purity (99.998%) argon flow while maintaining a chamber pressure of 22 mTorr under a high negative substrate voltage of 1300 V for 1 h and varying the target power from 0 to 67.5W. The process was initiated at room temperature and the heated sample was naturally cooled in a high-vacuum chamber.
To introduce nanostructure formation on a micro-roughened surface, sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched (SLA) disks with dimensions of 10⌀ ×5 mm were loaded into the deposition chamber. TIPS was conducted following the same procedure at a target power of 45 W for 7 min to minimize the reduction of the micro-roughness of the samples.

sections.heading: 2.2. Surface characterization
sections.text:
The surface topographies of the nanostructured sampleswere examined using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JSM6330F, JEOL). The surface chemical composition was determined using an SEM equipped with an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) device at 20 kV from three different points on each sample. Cross-sectional images of the nanostructure were prepared using a focused ion beam (FIB), and the chemical composition was examined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Tecnai F20, FEI) with EDS at 200 kV.
The hydrophilicities of the nano-, micro-, and hierarchical micronano structured surfaces were evaluated using the sessile drop method
with a contact angle analyzer (Phoenix 300, Surface Electro Optics). At room temperature, water droplets with the same amount (1.0 μL) were placed on a sample using a syringe and were measured three times after fully drying. The contact angle was analyzed using an image analysis program (Image XP).
The roughness of the micro- and hierarchical micro-nano structure was investigated using laser scanning microscopy (OLS 4100, Olympus, Japan). The surface of a 196×196 μm2 areawas scanned using a 50× objective lens and 405 nm light. The arithmetic mean height (Sa), root mean square height (Sq), kurtosis of the height distribution (Sku), and skewness of the height distribution (Ssk) of the surfaces were calculated using a provided software program.

sections.heading: 2.3. In vitro cellular assays
sections.text:
In vitro cell attachment and proliferation of the nano-,micro- and hierarchical micro-nano structured surfaces were investigated using MC3T3-E1 (ATCC, CRL-2593) pre-osteoblasts. Amirror-polished surface was compared as a control. The initial amount of pre-incubated cells seeded on the samples were 3×104 and 2×104 cells/mL for the cell attachment and proliferation assays, respectively. The culture medium consisted of α-minimum essential medium (α-MEM, Welgene), 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), and 1% penicillin–streptomycin.
The cell morphologies on the samples were examined using FESEM and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLMS; Zeiss-LSM510, Carl Zeiss) after 3 h of culturing. The cells were fixed using 2.5% glutaraldehyde for 10 min, dehydrated using 70, 90, 95, and 100% grade ethanol, immersed in hexamethyldisilazane, and dried for observation using FESEM. Furthermore, the cells on the samples were fixed using 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min, gently washed in phosphate buffered saline (PBS), permeabilized using 0.1% Triton X-100 for 7 min, and washed again in PBS. F-actin and cell nuclei were stained fluorescent red and blue using phalloidin and DAPI, respectively, for cell morphology observation using confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM).
The cell proliferation test was investigated using a methoxyphenyl tetrazolium salt (MTS) assay with 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-5-(3arboxymethoxyphenyl)-2-(4-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium (Promega, Madison). After culturing for 5 days, the quantity of the formazan product, from mitochondrial reduction, was measured from the 490 nm absorbance using a micro-reader (Model 550; Biorad) that could directly indicate the number of living cells on the sample.

sections.heading: 2.4. In vivo animal test
sections.text:
SLA-treated Ti6Al4V-ELI screws for dental implantswith dimensions of 3⌀ ×5 mmwere prepared as representatives of the microstructured surfaces. The hierarchical micro-nano structured surface was fabricated using TIPS with a sample rotor to uniformly etch the microstructured surface of the screw. The fabricated sampleswere sterilized using an autoclave and sealed until implantation.
Mongrel dogs (9 months old, male, weight range of 25±5 kg) were used for in vivo experiments. The animal selection, management, surgical protocol, and sacrificial procedures were approved by the Ethics Committee on the Animal Experimentation of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee, Cronex, Hwasung, Korea (CRONEX-IACUC 201506002). Teeth from the second premolar to the first molar of the mandible lower jaw bone were extracted to provide implantation sites. After 2 months of healing, each of the micro- and hierarchical micro-nano structured screws were implanted at the implantation sites drilled using a trephine drill (XTP 7408), followed by careful suturing of the soft tissues.
Eight weeks after the implantation, the mongrel dogs were sacrificed, and the extracted screws and adjacent tissues were fixed using 10% neutral formaldehyde solution and resin. Digital images of the resin block sections stained with Goldner's trichrome and haematoxylin-eosin were examined using optical microscopy (BX51,
Olympus). Mineralized bone tissues were stained green, distinguished from red-stained unmineralized osteoid. The bone-to-implant contact area ratio (BIC) of each sample was measured along the outline of the screw. The bone growth (BG) percentage was calculated as a ratio of the green stained area to the total area inside the notches of the screw from histological images using a digital image analysis program (ImageJ).

sections.heading: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sections.text: All experimental data were presented as themean± standard deviation using Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS 23, SPSS Inc., USA). Before analyzing the differences in data, a normality of variables was tested with a Shapiro-Wilk test. In the cases of wettability and proliferation (MTS) tests, one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed followed by least-square difference (LSD) post hoc comparison test. Student's t-test was used to evaluate the differences among in vivo results. A p-value below 0.05 was considered significant.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The target ion-induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) techniquewas conductedwith a Ta target in a DCmagnetron sputtering system. The application of an extremely high negative substrate bias of 1300 V generated an acceleration of Ta target ions with a high kinetic energy towards the substrate, resulting in severe surface etching and incorporation of Ta atoms into the surface [26]. These incorporated Ta atoms induced the local compositional variation, which is believed to be the origin of the surface nano-patterns under the ion-induced surface etching condition [32]. It was reported that the length and depth of the surface nano-patterns are affected by the negative substrate bias voltage, but the role of the Ta target powerwasnot discussed in the previous study [32]. During the TIPS process, the substrate voltage affects an increment of the amount of ion flux and the kinetic energy at the same time, which
makes it difficult to optimize the processing conditions for HMN structures. Therefore, in order to control the ion flux individually, the Ta target power that exhibited a correlationwith the Ta atom and ion number in the vacuum chamber was selected as the main processing parameter in this study.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of nanostructured Ti6Al4V surfaces
sections.text:
Prior to the fabrication of a HMN structure of Ti6Al4V-ELI, the effect of the Ta target power on the surface topography of flatTi6Al4V was investigated using FESEM images, as shown in Fig. 1. Without the use of a Ta target power, a smooth and flat surface was observed without any grinding traces, as shown in Fig. 1a, which had similar surface features as that of an Ar plasma-cleaned metal substrate with residual contaminants eliminated [33]. In contrast, under the application of a target power, surface topography was dramatically changed. In the cases of 22.5 and 45 W target powers, nano-patterned surface structures were uniformly developed with different sizes (Fig. 1b, c), and at the highest target power of 67.5 W, only sub-micron-sized rough structures were irregularly generated on the surface without a well-defined nano-structure (Fig. 1d).
The chemical composition of the TIPS-treated surfaces using various target powers was investigated using an EDS device attached to the FESEM, and is shown in Fig. 2. The spectrum of each surface was collected at 20 keV and analyzed using theprovided software (the corresponding spectra are shown in Fig. S1). The Ta amount incorporated in the near surface (the analytical depth of EDS was approximately 1–2 μm) was increased following an increase in the target power, but the total amount did not exceed to 7 at.%, which means that most Ta ions were re-sputtered from the substrate under the extremely high substrate voltage of 1300 V [34,35].
Cross-sections of the nano- and sub-micron-sized rough surfaces fabricated using target powers of 45 and 67.5 W were prepared using
rocess with different target powers; (a) 0, (b) 22.5, (c) 45, (d) 67.5 W.
FIB and examined using TEM, as shown in Fig. 3. In the case of 45 W, nano-patterned surface structures were uniformly distributed throughout the cross-sectional image with approximate depths and widths of
Fig. 3. TEMcross-sectional images of (a, b) 45 and (c) 67.5W target power conditions; (a) and (c analysis of the indicated points (1, 2) conducted at 200 kV with a spot size of 7.
350 and 65 nm, respectively. A Ta-rich region (the relatively brighter area in the TEM image [32]) was predominantly formed on the tips of the nano-patterned structures, and its quantity was approximately

80 at.% as measured using TEM-EDS (point 1 in Fig. 3). In the case of 67.5 W, the sub-micron-sized surface structure showed a wider distribution of a Ta-rich region than for the nano-patterned structure; this was further confirmed by Tamapping (the inset of Fig. 3c), and these regionswere predominantly formed at the upper part of the surface structures. TEM-EDS analysis at point 2 in Fig. 3 showed a similar amount of Ta for a target power of 45 W.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanism of nanostructured Ti6Al4V surface formationwith Ta target power variation
sections.text:
In the present study with a fixed substrate bias of 1300 V, we determined a critical range of target power for fabricating a nano-patterned surface structure on a Ti6Al4V-ELI substrate. An increase in the target power can effectively enhance the Ta ion flux onto the substrate, leading to an increase in the amount of incorporated Ta on the surface (Fig. 2). This is considered to be an important phenomenon for creating a nano-patterned surface structure using
the TIPS technique. Local compositional differences of surfaces may induce a local sputtering yield difference, and finally generate nano-sized height differences on the surface. In this study, over a target power of 22.5W, Ta ion inflow and the amount of incorporated Ta could exceed the critical point for inducing local compositional differences on the surface. As a result, fine-sized nano-patterned surfaces with gaps of b100 nm were fabricated. The higher Ta ion flux caused by increasing the target power led to severe surface etching and an increase in the amount of Ta incorporation on the surface, which induced the coarse separation of Ta-rich regions. This effect possibly intensified the difference in the etching rate between the top and bottom of the nano-patterns, resulting in an enlargement of the pattern gaps and depths. However, an excessively high power on the Ta target (65.5 W) made it difficult to fabricate surface nanostructures. A large amount of Ta incorporation on the surface produced sub-micron-sized Ta-rich regions, and within the similar chemical composition region, sputtering yield difference generation rarely occurred on the surface.

sections.heading: 3.3. Wettability of nano-patterned Ti6Al4V
sections.text:
The hydrophilicity, one of the most important properties for biocompatibility [36,37], of each specimen was investigated by measuring the contact angle of a distilledwater droplet on the surface (Fig. 4). Compared with a flat surface with a target power of 0 W, nano-sized surface structures (22.5 and 45W target powers) substantially changed the hydrophilicity of Ti6Al4V-ELI; as the size of the nano-patterned structure increased, the contact angle decreased significantly from 78.0±4.3° to 7.6±1.1°. This excellent hydrophilic property of the surfacenanostructure produced using a target power of 45W can generally be explained by the intensive water absorption through the sufficient size of pore structures to fill up with water because of the capillary effect and their high surface energy [38,39]. On the other hand, the sub-micron-sized rough surface (67.5 W target power) exhibited a similar contact angle as that of a flat-surface (71.2±1.2°). Irregular surface topography with small size of pores acts as an air pocket in which the water cannot enter the pores because of their size and closed structure, and the surface becomes hydrophobic [39]. Surfacewettability is directly related to the biological functionof biomaterials; hydrophilic surfacemakes it easy to approach thewater-based
cell media, and results in better adsorption of cell anchoring proteins to the implant surface [37,40,41]. Therefore, based on the wettability tests, the 45W target power was chosen as a TIPS processing condition for fabricating a hydrophilic HMN structure for further evaluations. The excellent hydrophilic properties of the surface nanostructures produced using a target power of 45W can generally be explained by the intensive water absorption of the nano-sized porous structure due to the capillary
, f, j, n) nano-, (c, g, k, o)micro-, and (d, h, l, p) hierarchicalmicro-nano structureswith low
effect and their high surface energy. Based on the wettability tests, the 45W target powerwas chosen as a TIPS processing condition for fabricating an HMN structure for further evaluations.

sections.heading: 3.4. Hierarchical Ti6Al4V surface structure
sections.text:
The HMN surface structure of Ti6Al4V-ELI was fabricated using the TIPS techniquewith a target power of 45Won an SLA-treated substrate. Compared with the relatively sharp surface structures of an SLA-treated specimen with micron-sized pits, ridges, and cavities, the TIPS-treated specimen exhibited slightly blunted morphologies that maintained their surface roughness, as shown in Fig. 5. From a high magnification image of the TIPS-treated specimen (Fig. 5d), nano-sized surface structures was generated uniformly throughout the entire surface following the complex geometry of Ti6Al4V-ELI. To quantify the surface roughness, the arithmetic mean height (Sa), root mean square height (Sq), kurtosis of the height distribution (Sku) and skewness of the height distribution (Ssk) of the micro and HMN structured surfaces were
examined using laser scanning microscopy (LSM) (Fig. 5e, f) with provided software. All the values of the surface roughness are shown in Table 1, and there was no significant difference between the micronsized and the HMN structure; the Sa and Sq values of themicrostructure decreased by only 4% after TIPS treatment, and the distribution of the surface height (Sku and Ssk values) exhibited almost identical roughness ranges.
The wettability of the HMN structure was also examined and is shown in Table 1 with that of a surface with micron-sized roughness (SLA-treated surface). Likewise, from the results of wettability with flat specimens (Fig. 4), the surface nanostructure significantly reduced the water contact angle from 99.3±9.4° to nearly zero; a water drop on the HMN structure spread out and was completely absorbed into the surface. The superhydrophilic behavior (a contact angle below 10°) of the HMN-structured surface was due to the favorable effect of water and surface nanostructure interaction combined with micronsized surface roughness [41,42]. In general, such superhydrophilic surfaces have great potential for promoting protein adsorption and cellular responses, especially bone cell maturation and differentiation, which is closely associated with the direct bonding and earlier stabilization of dental implants [43–45].

sections.heading: 3.5. In vitro cellular responses
sections.text:
To validate the biological effect of the HMN structure, cell attachment and proliferation of pre-osteoblasts (MC3T3-E1) on the HMN structured surface were investigated using flat, nano-, and micro-structured surfaces. The cell attachment morphologies after 3 h of culturing were investigated using FESEM and CLSM, as shown in Fig. 6. On the nano-patterned surface structure, cells were flattened with a higher number of filopodia, and F-actin (filamentous actin) was more concentrated at the spreading edge of the cell than the flat surface of the Ti6Al4V-ELI substrate (Fig. 6f, n). Filopodia is generally considered to be the ‘antennae’ of cells. It contains several receptors that recognize various signaling biomolecules and components of the extracellularmatrix [46]. Therefore, abundant filopodia formation of the cells on the nano-sized surface structure implies that the sensing and signaling of the attached cell was highly activated. Implanted Ta in the topmost surface is another factor contributing to better cell attachment. In the previous studies, cuboidal 3D cellular morphologies with more filopodia were observed on the Ta-coated Ti substrate than the bare one [47];
implanted and condensed atoms have high surface energy and low contact angle because of the presence of atomic defects and the migration from the lower energy sites,which can also enhance initial cell adhesion behaviors [48].
In the case of micron-sized surface structure (SLA-treated surface), cells with a polygonal shape were poorly attached on the roughness; some tips of filopodia were anchored on the surface, but most parts of the cell membranes were not attached and were torn during the SEM observation process (Fig. 6g). The relatively hydrophobic property of the SLA-treated surface adversely affected the cell attachment behaviors in the early stages of culturing, and this type of poor cell adhesion on an SLA-treated surface has been commonly found inmany previous studies [6,43,44,49–52]. When the nanostructure was combined with the microstructure of SLA, the adhesionmorphology of the osteoblast was dramatically changed; the cells were fully attached and followed the surface geometry without any delamination (Fig. 6d, h). This result is clear evidence of highly active interactions between the cells and the nano-structured surfaces.
From the results of the MTS assay after 5 days of culturing (Fig. 7), the level of cell proliferation was found to be strongly affected by the surface roughness. The active interaction of the attached cells with the nanostructure, and the provision of a large surface area from themicrostructure led to significant enhancement of the cell proliferation compared to a flat surface. By combining these individual effects on cell behaviors, the HMN structure exhibited a significantly higher proliferation level than the others structures (p b 0.05) [45,53,54].

sections.heading: 3.6. In vivo bone regeneration
sections.text: To evaluate the clinical performance of the HMN surface structure, an in vivo pilot study was performed with eight mandible defects in one dog. A microstructured (SLA-treated) surface was used as a control group that is representative of the surface morphology in dental applications. After 8 weeks of implantation, the micro- and HMN-structured implant screws were extracted with the adjacent tissues and prepared as specimens for histological observations. The regenerated bone tissues were stained using Goldner's trichrome method and distinguished using two colors; green formineralized andmature bone and red for osteoid, which is unmineralized tissue (Fig. 8a, c). As shown in the histological images, the HMN-structured surface exhibited a higher boneto-implant contact area and mineralized bone (the ratio of green to red stained parts) in the defect site than the microstructured surface (Fig. 8b, d). The relative percentage of the bone-to-implant contact (BIC) area and new bone volume (NBV) of each surface was assessed using an image analysis program (Fig. 9), and the result shows that the HMN structured surface exhibited enhanced BIC and NBV values compared to the microstructured surface. These in vivo results verified that the HMN structure substantially enhanced the entire healing process of bonedefectswith strongmechanicalfixation due to its active cellular interactions and superhydrophilicity [55].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
A hierarchical micro-nano (HMN) surface structure was fabricated using the TIPS technique on a Ti6Al4V-ELI substrate, which had been previously sand-blasted with large-grit and acid-etched, and the processing condition was optimized by adjusting the Ta target power. The fabricated HMN surface structure exhibited a uniform distribution of the nanostructure on the surface with micron-sized roughness and superhydrophilicity that substantially increased the cellular activities of the SLA-treated surface. For a dog mandible model, the bone-to-implant contact area and new bone volume were also enhanced on the HMN surface structure. These results indicate that this HMN structure is a promising surface structure for resolving the lack of cellular activity and poor clinical performance of SLA-treated Ti-based alloys.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx. doi.org/10.1016/j.msec.2016.12.064.

sections.text: This work was supported by the Technology Innovation Program (contract grant no. 10047860, Selective Plasma Etching (SPE) surface treatment for vascular stent and the development of low temperature complex coating technology for drug), and Industrial Strategic Technology Development Program (contract grant no. 10045329, Development of customized implant with porous structure for bone replacement), funded by the Ministry of Trade, Industry & Energy (MI, Korea).

referenceMentions.context: Among them, Ti6Al4V-ELI, which possesses superior mechanical properties, is the most favored Ti-based alloy havingwide applications as an implantmaterial in dentistry [4,5].
Among them, Ti6Al4V-ELI, which possesses superior mechanical properties, is the most favored Ti-based alloy havingwide applications as an implantmaterial in dentistry [4,5].
Among the various surface modification techniques, sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched (SLA) is the most successfully commercialized surface treatment for Ti-based dental implants [13,14].
Among the various surface modification techniques, sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched (SLA) is the most successfully commercialized surface treatment for Ti-based dental implants [13,14].

However, in the case of Ti-based alloys, inferior osteoblast cell adhesion behavior in the early stage of the implantation of SLAtreated Ti-based alloys still remains as the main problem [13,15].

Target-ion induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) is a recently developed technique which combines the advantages of conventional ion beam etching and sputtering; conventional ion beam etching can fabricate nano-scale surface structures while maintaining metallic properties [27–29], and sputtering can fabricate such surface structures on a large surface area in mass-production [30,31].

Target-ion induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) is a recently developed technique which combines the advantages of conventional ion beam etching and sputtering; conventional ion beam etching can fabricate nano-scale surface structures while maintaining metallic properties [27–29], and sputtering can fabricate such surface structures on a large surface area in mass-production [30,31].

When tantalum (Ta) was used as a target material, a highly porous titanium surface created with Ta ion incorporation exhibited not only excellent biocompatibility, but also enhanced osteoblast responses in in vitro situations [26,32].

When tantalum (Ta) was used as a target material, a highly porous titanium surface created with Ta ion incorporation exhibited not only excellent biocompatibility, but also enhanced osteoblast responses in in vitro situations [26,32].

The application of an extremely high negative substrate bias of 1300 V generated an acceleration of Ta target ions with a high kinetic energy towards the substrate, resulting in severe surface etching and incorporation of Ta atoms into the surface [26].
These incorporated Ta atoms induced the local compositional variation, which is believed to be the origin of the surface nano-patterns under the ion-induced surface etching condition [32].

It was reported that the length and depth of the surface nano-patterns are affected by the negative substrate bias voltage, but the role of the Ta target powerwasnot discussed in the previous study [32].

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 25 August 2016 Received in revised form 18 November 2016 Accepted 13 December 2016 Available online 18 December 2016 Hierarchical micro-nano (HMN) surface structuring of dental implants is a fascinating strategy for achieving fast and mechanically stable fixation due to the synergetic effect of microand nano-scale surface roughness with surrounding tissues. However, the introduction of awell-defined nanostructure on amicrostructure having complex surface geometry is still challenging. As a means of fabricating HMN surface on Ti6Al4V-ELI, target-ion induced plasma sputtering (TIPS) was used onto a sand-blasted, large-grit and acid-etched substrate. The HMN surface topography was simply controlled by adjusting the tantalum (Ta) target power of the TIPS technique, which is directly related to the Ta ion flux and the surface chemical composition of the substrate. Characterization using scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM), transmission electronmicroscopy (TEM), and laser scanningmicroscopy (LSM) verified that well-defined nano-patterned surface structures with a depth of ~300 to 400 nm and a width of ~60 to 70 nmwere uniformly distributed and followed the complex micron-sized surface geometry. In vitro cellular responses of pre-osteoblast cells (MC3T3-E1)were assessed by attachment and proliferation of cells on flat, nano-roughened, micro-roughened, and an HMN surface structure of Ti6Al4V-ELI. Moreover, an in vivo dogmandible defect model study was used to investigate the biological effect of the HMN surface structure compared with the micro-roughened surface. The results showed that the surface nanostructure significantly increased the cellular activities of flat and micro-roughened Ti, and the bone-to-implant contact area and new bone volume were significantly improved on the HMN surface structured Ti. These results support the idea that an HMN surface structure on Ti6Al4V-ELI alloy has great potential for enhancing the biological performance of dental implants. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
